Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Solving Large-Scale, High-Fidelity Workforce Planning Models that Recognize the Potential of Human Learning

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this award is the development of optimization models, solution methods for those models, and insights that will enable organizations to perform workforce planning while recognizing the near and long-term effects of human learning. These optimization models will be based on descriptive, quantitative models of human learning. Developed by the organizational psychology community, the (nonlinear) shape of these learning models makes them a challenge to use in optimization. This work overcomes this challenge by encoding the nonlinear relationship between experience level and learning into a parameter that can be computed outside of the optimization. Having mitigated the challenge of the learning curves, the work will develop more realistic optimization models that recognize operational considerations, the potential of training and cross-training activities, and uncertainty in learning parameters and future tasks to be performed. The improved realism of our workforce planning models will bring new computational challenges, and the research will develop new solution methods. Computational experiments and analysis will be performed to derive insights into how learning impacts workforce planning and strategies for using these insights for maximum benefit.

If successful, this research will produce tools that organizations can use to enhance their competitiveness in the near term and to position their workforce to take advantage of future opportunities. These tools will help organizations make decisions involving hiring and training activities, as well as understand the tradeoffs between hiring and training/re-training. Further, developed solution methods, particularly those related to linearizing nonlinear functions, are applicable in other contexts. The multi-disciplinary nature of the project, which if successful, will yield publications in both operations management/research and organizational psychology journals could bridge the gap between those disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The models and methods developed during this project offer a means by which one can optimize workforce planning. From our optimization perspective, the project's most important impact was the introduction of a reformulation technique to linearize math programs that incorporate nonlinear models of learning while also having broader application to any math program that incorporates a nonlinear function with a discrete domain. Further, we have shown how to apply a capacity-scaling algorithm to the reformulated math program to reduce computation time.

Our work then incorporated the technique into the development of additional new optimization techniques for solving workforce planning problems, and notably problems that account for random demand. One such development is a mathheuristic for solving two-stage stochastic programming models of workforce planning models that incorporate human learning and demand uncertainty. This matheuristic is the first solution approach for solving stochastic workforce planning problems wherein heterogeneous workers learn.

Our work also introduces an approximate dynamic programming approach, specifically a value function approximation, for the problem of scheduling technicians to jobs over a long horizon in which demand is uncertain. We show that, while the problem does not possess the properties (e.g. monotonicity, concavity/convexity) often exploited in ADP approaches, a linear value-function approximation still offers good approximations despite the nonlinearity.

As part of simulations performed in the testing of the models and algorithms, the work identified several results that are of interest to managers who must hire and schedule workers. Our most important contribution is to show the value an organization can achieve by sacrificing productivity in the near-term to appropriately position its workforce with respect to experience. Further, the results of associated with actively managing workforce learning are achieved relatively early in the problem horizon. That is, the important results of accounting for the future impact of experience are achieved within of a few weeks or a month. After that, one need only assign the best worker to the job without worrying about the accumulation of experience.

Our work also shows that, at the tactical level, a manufacturer should direct workforce capacity in addition to hold inventory as a hedge against uncertainty in demands, as doing so leads to lower inventory and greater profits. As both directing capacity and holding inventory may require additional managerial effort, we show for which type of product each strategy should be applied. Specifically, we show that it is effective to rely on inventory for one product and on responsive capacity for the other. As the ability to direct capacity is a function of a workforce’s learning capabilities, which may differ by organization, we identify for which types of workforces an organization should focus on managing their capacity development instead of building inventory. In particular, we show that manufacturers with workforces that learn quickly should focus on building their productivity, while those with workforces that learn more slowly should build more inventory. Given the effectiveness associated with both directing capacity as well as holding inventory, manufacturers should consider should the workforces capacity to learn in making job assignments and should strongly consider learning capabilities in their hiring practices.

At an operational perspective, we offer insights into how to manage individual employees. A fundamental question in workforce management is to determine which individuals should specialize (i.e. become highly proficient at one or two tasks at the expense of low proficiency in other tasks) and which should cross train (i.e. achieve a reasonable level of proficiency at many tasks). We answer this question in the context of recognizing the potential to both direct workforce capacity and hold inventory by identifying which individuals, based on their learning parameters, should specialize and which should cross train. The results show that both slower learners and those with the potential to achieve higher productivity should specialize more. Faster learners are best suited for cross training. Nonetheless, each worker should a variety of tasks. That is, the workforce should be cross-trained. Finally and relatedly, our results show that we obtain better solutions when the workload is more balanced across all workers, even the slow and inexperienced ones.

Incorporating these insights and using our optimization models can help American industry become more productive, driving the competitiveness of the American economy and wages of its workforce.
